item.name: There are 2 different modes to control the hang glider on ground: walking and running.
walking: - forced movement with fixed step size
running: - motion due to external forces/moments
- superimposes walking-mode
Controls:
mode | forward/backward | sideward | turning |
walking | arrow up/down | arrow left/right | Insert/Enter |
running | increase/decrease throttle | - | rudder |
The running force (forward) is set to 0 by once only pressing 3/PgDn (backward) and vice versa.
Same control behavior with walking (Movement stops after 1x pressing the opposite direction).
Once in air all forces are set to 0.
Breaks ("b") are usable.
The parking-brake ("B") is set automatically after inserting the legs.
Running forces release the parking-brake automatically (see BREAK-instrument in panel).
Recover (pick yourself up after a crash) with "r"
Take-off:
Positioning and alignment in "walking"-mode
From mountain: Run forward ("running"-mode)
From flat terrain: "s" + increase throttle or Ctrl-U
Touch down:
1. erect pilot (this is important for reasonable flares!)
2. wait until running animation starts (altitude less than 10ft)
3. reduce speed to trim speed while keeping altitude
4. push A-frame (pull joystick/mouse)
Note:
Perfect landing: You are still on your feet after the flare (with parking brake on)
Good landing: Try to run-it-out (parking brake off)
Bad landing: ... press "r"
Ctrl-w: place winch
w : clutch in / de-clutch winch
W : release rope
- Configure the winch via the GUI.
- Choose the "chest" or "belly" hook. It's purely a matter of taste.
(Note: Up to now the hook-shift is only animated but NOT modelled in the fdm!)
- Release the parking-brake before launch.
Step towing:
1. After coming up over the winch, don't release the tow ...
2. ... de-clutch the winch instead ("w").
3. Quickly turn downwind and fly back to over the launch position.
4. Slowly turn back upwind. Be careful not to touch the rope with your wing!
5. Clutch in the winch ("w") and perform the next step.
6. Usually you should end up higher than in the previous step.
7. Repeat as necessary.
Ctrl-o: find towplane and hook in
o : hook in
O : release tow
- Configure aerotow via the GUI.
- Choose the "chest" or "belly" hook. It's purely a matter of taste.
(Note: Up to now the hook-shift is only animated but NOT modelled in the fdm!)
- Chose the "drop" hook for balloon-towing.
- In real life the weak link is "very weak" due to safety reasons.
- Maybe you want to increase the break force of the weak link via the GUI.
- Ensure that the parking brake is released ("B").
- It is recommended to start running during launch to reduce the rope-strain.
Balloon drop:
(Experimental)
1. Set weak link break force to max.
2. Recommended rope lenght is 5-10m.
3. Recommended rope elastic constant is 5000-10000N (?)
4. Choose "drop" hook.
5. Erect pilot.
Due to a lack in the FDM-implementation the glider likely starts bouncing and
oscillating if the pilot is in a prone position.
The system is more stable with an upright pilot.
In real life a tumble starts, if the angle of attack becomes markedly negative.
This could occur in strong turbulence or (failed) aerobatics.
A tumble is caused due to weight shift and the spatial distance between the
center of gravity and the aero reference point.
Hence tumbling is a unique feature of hang gliders.
In the upside down phase the pilot falls into the sail. This often breaks the wing.
But even if the glider stays intact, it is nearly impossible to recover from a tumble.
The only way out is throwing the rescue parachute.
Here, tumbling is implemented in a very empirical way.
Nevertheless, tumble onset is pretty close to the real thing!
Due to the implementation it IS possible to recover. But it is extremely difficult.
Thus don't lose time and throw the chute ("}")!
